bullets.text: Trump–Zelensky talks aimed to advance a Ukraine peace deal, but core disputes still block agreement, keeping war-risk premium and sanctions uncertainty elevated.
Ukraine’s mooted 20-point plan remains a framework with unresolved enforcement, security guarantees, and sequencing—key determinants of future aid flows and reconstruction financing.
Middle East outlook described as an inflection point; persistent conflict and shifting alliances raise volatility for energy routes, defense spending, and regional investment.
Deadly protests in Syria over security underscore state fragility, complicating humanitarian operations and any credible path to stabilization, investment, or refugee returns.
A U.S. “zero immigration” scenario implies tighter labor supply, slower potential growth, and higher wage inflation pressures—especially in services, agriculture, and caregiving.
Big Tech’s agenda under Trump centers on A.I., chips, and regulation; policy choices could reshape antitrust risk, government procurement, and capital spending in compute.
Trump–Petro tensions spotlight Colombia’s pivotal role in global cocaine supply; reduced cooperation could alter interdiction effectiveness and spill into trade and security ties.
Year-end markets: U.S. stock futures flat after strong multi-year gains; investors debate whether momentum can persist amid still-tight financial conditions.
Quantum computing shows technical progress, but public-market payoffs remain uncertain; valuations may be most sensitive to near-term commercial milestones versus research headlines.
Restaurants’ 2025 best-seller was “value,” signaling sustained consumer price sensitivity; operators may face margin pressure without productivity gains or input-cost relief.
Coupang’s $1.1B user compensation for a data breach highlights rising cyber-liability, potential regulatory tightening, and material cash costs for consumer platforms.
A.I. datacenter demand is tightening chips and memory supply, risking higher device prices and reinforcing compute as a key inflation vector in electronics supply chains.
Hidden geothermal heat beneath Greenland could shift sea-level projections, affecting coastal risk pricing, insurance, and infrastructure planning.
